These underwear would have been very handy back then!

snippet.textDisplay:
Okay, lots to say here.
1. If you use a single use option, pad, tampon, sponge, etc. and you need to dispose of it while in public or at a friend's home (or your home) you are meant to wrap it up first. That is why the wrappers are plasticky. If you tossed the wrapper, you are meant to use toilet paper.

2. The finger covers there are just ridiculous! Blood is not corrosive, get over it, you have your period, use a bit of toilet paper to wipe your fingers if need be.

3. If you NEED finger covers, look in the first aid section of the drug store for "finger condoms." They unroll on your fingers the way regular condoms unroll on a penis and are easily removed, simply by rerolling them.

4. Not everyone has the option of wearing a cup, so stop acting like women who choose other options are somehow flawed. I would love the option of a cup, but within minutes of insertion, I develop a blinding migraine. Ignored it quickly because extremely painful cramps, nausea & vomiting, and eventually I will seize. I've tried multiple brands, it's the same with them all - and it was the same with tampons.

5. Period panties can be worn without pads or cups on light days. They are essentially a "light day" pad which is meant to help prevent leaks.

6. The "leaks" you saw in your water test resulted from the fact that they were not being worn and the fast flow of liquid. If you were to dump water onto ANY absorbent material that quickly it would do the same thing. And because the panties were not on a person, their was a clear ledge for the water to run off of, that does not exist when they are worn.

7. Also, if anything is losing that much blood that quickly they need to worry more about getting to the hospital than if their underwear are overflowing.

8. Natural sponges are a great option for those women who want an internal product but can not use a cup. Also, unlike the cup, natural sponges are easily and quickly biodegradable. They are also highly renewable, low production cost, and can be used by women in developing nations where water is in short supply (since cups need to be sanitized).

It's great that you want to discuss periods and famine hygiene products. But when you present them as "strange" or make comments like "just get a cup" you're not doing women a favor. These options all exist because women and periods are NOT one size fits all. Please stop behaving as if they are.

1. If you use a single use option, pad, tampon, sponge, etc. and you need to dispose of it while in public or at a friend's home (or your home) you are meant to wrap it up first. That is why the wrappers are plasticky. If you tossed the wrapper, you are meant to use toilet paper.

2. The finger covers there are just ridiculous!  Blood is not corrosive, get over it, you have your period, use a bit of toilet paper to wipe your fingers if need be. 

3. If you NEED finger covers, look in the first aid section of the drug store for "finger condoms." They unroll on your fingers the way regular condoms unroll on a penis and are easily removed, simply by rerolling them. 

4. Not everyone has the option of wearing a cup, so stop acting like women who choose other options are somehow flawed. I would love the option of a cup, but within minutes of insertion, I develop a blinding migraine. Ignored it quickly because extremely painful cramps, nausea & vomiting, and eventually I will seize. I've tried multiple brands, it's the same with them all - and it was the same with tampons. 

5. Period panties can be worn without pads or cups on light days. They are essentially a "light day" pad which is meant to help prevent leaks. 

6. The "leaks" you saw in your water test resulted from the fact that they were not being worn and the fast flow of liquid. If you were to dump water onto ANY absorbent material that quickly it would do the same thing. And because the panties were not on a person, their was a clear ledge for the water to run off of, that does not exist when they are worn. 

7. Also, if anything is losing that much blood that quickly they need to worry more about getting to the hospital than if their underwear are overflowing. 

8. Natural sponges are a great option for those women who want an internal product but can not use a cup. Also, unlike the cup, natural sponges are easily and quickly biodegradable. They are also highly renewable, low production cost, and can be used by women in developing nations where water is in short supply (since cups need to be sanitized).

snippet.textDisplay: Menstrual cup for the win! I started using one in 2006 and used it up until my hysterectomy in 2013. I was a very heavy bleeder so couldn’t use the cup on its own, I had to combine it with a pad, most commonly a night pad and it still happened that I would bleed through both cup and pad within a few hours on the worst days. One morning when I woke up after not very much sleep (had been up to bathroom at maybe 2am before going to sleep and emptied cup then as well, woke up at 8am or so and had then overfilled the cup, bled through the night pad and my pants and bed looked like a murder scene! Before using a cup I was using tampons and had to combine super plus tampons with night pad and already within about 2 years of having periods, I’d bleed through a super plus tampon within a few hours. It was just absolutely awful with periods, both the amounts I had to deal with, how long my periods usually lasted (often 7-10 days before I didn’t need to wear even a panty liner) and the absolutely horrendous cramps I had, along with migraines... Since I had my surgery in 2013 I’ve barely had even one migraine attack and I used to have them almost every month. I still have my ovaries but Lord Voldemort lost his last horcrux (which was an IUD in combination with mini pills) and was killed once and for all on September 26th 2013, that day was among the best days of my life!
snippet.textOriginal: Menstrual cup for the win! I started using one in 2006 and used it up until my hysterectomy in 2013. I was a very heavy bleeder so couldn’t use the cup on its own, I had to combine it with a pad, most commonly a night pad and it still happened that I would bleed through both cup and pad within a few hours on the worst days. One morning when I woke up after not very much sleep (had been up to bathroom at maybe 2am before going to sleep and emptied cup then as well, woke up at 8am or so and had then overfilled the cup, bled through the night pad and my pants and bed looked like a murder scene! Before using a cup I was using tampons and had to combine super plus tampons with night pad and already within about 2 years of having periods, I’d bleed through a super plus tampon within a few hours. It was just absolutely awful with periods, both the amounts I had to deal with, how long my periods usually lasted (often 7-10 days before I didn’t need to wear even a panty liner) and the absolutely horrendous cramps I had, along with migraines... Since I had my surgery in 2013 I’ve barely had even one migraine attack and I used to have them almost every month. I still have my ovaries but Lord Voldemort lost his last horcrux (which was an IUD in combination with mini pills) and was killed once and for all on September 26th 2013, that day was among the best days of my life!

snippet.textDisplay: My best friends don't have a bin in their bathroom
snippet.textOriginal: My best friends don't have a bin in their bathroom

snippet.textDisplay:
I have a menstrual cup and it is the best thing ever. My period is super light so I empty and rinse it in the morning and at night.
Honestly when I used tampons I flushed them, and I think most people do. Apparently you’re technically supposed to flush toilet paper and people definitely do. For the first pink sponge tampon, if I was using it and had to stick it in a regular garbage bin like at a friends’ as you mentioned I would rinse it out, squeeze out the excess and wrap it in toilet paper. But why go through all that effort and waste when you can use a menstrual cup.
As for the sea sponge causing toxic shock syndrome, tampons can do that (instructions tell you to not leave them in for more than 8 hours) and I expect so could that first pink sponge tampon. But menstrual cups don’t. One of the many many reasons I love menstrual cups.
The absorbent underwear I think would be good for people with heavy flows concerned about leaking used in addition to a tampon, or when you know your period will start soon or at the tail end when you only have light spotting. But I would suggest you check out Thinx period underwear. Multiple styles, a few different absorbency levels and they full replace tampons/pads. I haven’t used them myself but I know someone who does and loves them and is quite active. If I were going for period underwear I’d go Thinx.
snippet.textOriginal:

For the first pink sponge tampon, if I was using it and had to stick it in a regular garbage bin like at a friends’ as you mentioned I would rinse it out, squeeze out the excess and wrap it in toilet paper. But why go through all that effort and waste when you can use a menstrual cup. 
As for the sea sponge causing toxic shock syndrome, tampons can do that (instructions tell you to not leave them in for more than 8 hours) and I expect so could that first pink sponge tampon. But menstrual cups don’t. One of the many many reasons I love menstrual cups. 
The absorbent underwear I think would be good for people with heavy flows concerned about leaking used in addition to a tampon, or when you know your period will start soon or at the tail end when you only have light spotting. But I would suggest you check out Thinx period underwear. Multiple styles, a few different absorbency levels and they full replace tampons/pads. I haven’t used them myself but I know someone who does and loves them and is quite active. If I were going for period underwear I’d go Thinx.

snippet.textDisplay:
⚠️REMOVING BLOOD⚠️
Anything with blood on is best washed by running under cold water. Hot water sets the blood in. So I rinse in cold water to get out as much as possible then ace bleach for coloured clothes is great for taking the rest out. Hope this help someone 👍🏻

snippet.textDisplay:
I love that you're being open about periods and share that you use a menstrual cup. I do wish you hadn't used the word "weird" to describe them however as I fear people will see this as a jokey video and not see these as serious options. I use reusable period underwear (ones you bleed into not as backup) and reusable cloth pads and it's the best thing I ever did for the comfort of my body and the environment too. They say disposables have chemicals in that encourage bleeding and I didn't really believe that but since I switched my periods last 3 days instead of 5.
As for washing the pants you have to check with each brand what the manufacturer advises but I put mine on a rinse cycle then wash at 40 degrees with just detergent no fabric conditioner.
snippet.textOriginal:
I love that you're being open about periods and share that you use a menstrual cup. I do wish you hadn't used the word "weird" to describe them however as I fear people will see this as a jokey video and not see these as serious options. I use reusable period underwear (ones you bleed into not as backup) and reusable cloth pads and it's the best thing I ever did for the comfort of my body and the environment too. They say disposables have chemicals in that encourage bleeding and I didn't really believe that but since I switched my periods last 3 days instead of 5.
As for washing the pants you have to check with each brand what the manufacturer advises but I put mine on a rinse cycle then wash at 40 degrees with just detergent no fabric conditioner.

snippet.textDisplay: I think the period pants are for helping with leaks maybe? Like if you don't change your pad/tampon in time and end up leaking a little, the pants are absorbent enough to stop it from showing through on your trousers/skirt. I have seen pants like what you're thinking of - Safiya Nygaard tested them out, with varying results (depended on how heavy she was) - but I think the ones you bought are just for helping with leaks.

snippet.textDisplay:
Pads as shown on the packaging, you use the packaging of the next pad to throw away the worn one. It's much better than wasting toilet paper too on each one, just use toilet paper for the last pad you put on. Tampons should NOT be flushed down the toilet much like you wouldn't with a pad or nappies etc. They clog the drains and costs a lot of money to get blockages sorted and as you'd imagine it wouldn't be a nice job for the poor person who has to sort that... also tampons are one of our worst polluters and there's much more chance of it ended up in our ocean.

Some girls can have really heavy periods and leak wearing a tampon/ pad so those underwear could be great for them or just for some more security maybe for sleeping in or to not have that worry of leaking on your clothing.


Also with those sea sponges, Jazz says that they can cause TSS (toxic shock syndrome) also bear in mind that tampons also can cause that. Bacteria from the sea doesn't sound too good! xD
snippet.textOriginal:
Pads as shown on the packaging, you use the packaging of the next pad to throw away the worn one. It's much better than wasting toilet paper too on each one, just use toilet paper for the last pad you put on. Tampons should NOT be flushed down the toilet much like you wouldn't with a pad or nappies etc. They clog the drains and costs a lot of money to get blockages sorted and as you'd imagine it wouldn't be a nice job for the poor person who has to sort that... also tampons are one of our worst polluters and there's much more chance of it ended up in our ocean. 

Some girls can have really heavy periods and leak wearing a tampon/ pad so those underwear could be great for them or just for some more security maybe for sleeping in or to not have that worry of leaking on your clothing.


Also with those sea sponges, Jazz says that they can cause TSS (toxic shock syndrome) also bear in mind that tampons also can cause that.  Bacteria from the sea doesn't sound too good! xD

For the situations when you're at your friend's house and their bin is weird for whatever reason I carry around plastic sacks or zip lock bags and you can wrap the tampon or the sponge in toilet paper, put it in the baggy and throw it into the bin. It's just that simple 🤷🏻‍♀️
And the panties are actually really great because so many people, including me, have a heavier flow especially during the night if anything were to happen.

snippet.textDisplay: I use my cup and period panties together, but when I'm just spotting I then only use my panties. To wash I just throw them in the sink and rinse, but they're never full, however I also use reusable pads. I've used the cup, pads and undies for 7 years without ever leaking. With tampons I wear pads too and I do wrap them in tp in public or my pad wrapper if I'm at home. I cramp less and have shorter lighter periods since switching to all reusable products and gotten away from the fragrance and dyes.
snippet.textOriginal: I use my cup and period panties together, but when I'm just spotting I then only use my panties. To wash I just throw them in the sink and rinse, but they're never full, however I also use reusable pads. I've used the cup, pads and undies for 7 years without ever leaking. With tampons I wear pads too and I do wrap them in tp in public or my pad wrapper if I'm at home. I cramp less and have shorter lighter periods since switching to all reusable products and gotten away from the fragrance and dyes.

snippet.textDisplay: When I’ve used disposable products I used to keep a ziplock sandwich bag in my handbag and I’d wrap pads up in the wrapper of the new pad and then in a tissue and pop in my ziplock bag when I was out. Then I’d throw them out when I got home. I’d imagine I’d do the same with tampons if I were to go back to disposables.
snippet.textOriginal: When I’ve used disposable products I used to keep a ziplock sandwich bag in my handbag and I’d wrap pads up in the wrapper of the new pad and then in a tissue and pop in my ziplock bag when I was out. Then I’d throw them out when I got home. I’d imagine I’d do the same with tampons if I were to go back to disposables.

snippet.textDisplay: the period under wear is fr when you dont have a heavy period then you dont have to use pad with them

snippet.textDisplay: When you push the sponge up in you it will need to be squeezed. And blood is thicker than water and its sticky and dried faster than water so the sponge will not drip like water does.
snippet.textOriginal: When you push the sponge up in you it will need to be squeezed. And blood is thicker than water and its sticky and dried faster than water so the sponge will not drip like water does.

snippet.textDisplay: You wrap it in toilet paper and throw it away. That's how you throw away a max pad as well.

snippet.textDisplay: Thinx period panties are pants actually made for wearing by themselves on lighter flow days,  those could be good for like "free bleed" days. I personally just "free bleed" at night after my first day of flow because it pretty much stops cause of gravity.
snippet.textOriginal: Thinx period panties are pants actually made for wearing by themselves on lighter flow days,  those could be good for like "free bleed" days. I personally just "free bleed" at night after my first day of flow because it pretty much stops cause of gravity.

snippet.textDisplay: the pants are meant for if you spill, so you don't get any blood on your jeans.
